A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

I
Incidentally, it was during years before I made any great visit to England. I heard our family physician at Hillburn, and wrote often.

That summer 1892 I had a cow by mail. The next year I worked for a Canadian (not a green-eyed Ishmael) or $3 per month. (1893)

I paid back up new land with New Mexico.

The settlers in this district came there in 1882.

My uncle, Mr. Eddy, lived at South Elmo, about 1 mile west of Ontario.

In 1894 I bought a farm (240 acres) for $880 in the Hillburn District. Buying it to farm, I lived in a log shanty on the farm.

I was watching a child out in the spring with 25 cents. I met a Canadian (not a pioneer) before he started his own claim for a pre-emption. That summer, I was so hard up the friend turned hunt my first through the hole in my head, and I was thrown down on my back.

Next, it was hard work clearing heavy brush with an axe or bucking the land with two horses in the fall. The rain came all bundled in bales of hay, shipped from the carriers in boxes of dirt and always a bad dream.

(Mr. North Star, Alta.)
It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences; others may prove less experienced.

If you were a boy in the family and the question came from the head of house, you would probably have a good copy of what you had to write.

And if you had a good copy of what you had to write, you could use it to make a good job of answering the question.

You could also use your own handwriting if you thought it looked good enough.

I couldn't have done that without the guidance of my parents.

I was delighted to receive your kind letter.

Your son's name is mentioned by Mr. Roy F. Hannah.

He became No. 18969 and was named at the age of 14.

He died in 1952.

I am glad you wrote back so soon.

I wonder how you are doing now.

I hope you are well and happy.

I am looking forward to hearing from you again.

With best wishes,

[Signature]

October 11

[Signature]
There was a farm on the farm and the Indians came there to pitch tents at noon. While bathing I liked for syrup or tea. Mulling am. Prunes of rice. So I had a good crop that fall but the wheat had a brown frost. I heeled it 15 miles to Hopilla near of the farm and sold it for $366 per bus.

and sold goods from the store. In 1895 I was buying around 14 hours a day. On morning I went to the store of this man in a Red River cart. The pull-up three days in a printed shirt and pants. I walked away toward the poplars.

On December 4th 1895 I was married at the Methodist Church at Millburn. There was a Methodist Church at Millburn at this time which we attended.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A series of questionnaires to the pioneer settlers of the North West Territories.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual life is such as to answer it as easily as the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. You are free to select or reject them as you see fit. If there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, please use additional sheets.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1941 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for separate questionnaires.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

   CPR

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
   When train stopped over at Winnipeg half a dozen guys went up main street where there was a wooden pump halfway up. We stripped off coats & one pumped until the rest had a good cold sweat. This was in March & the natives of Winnipeg got the excitement.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

About three times a year.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My husband's name was William. Married 4th December 1895 at Shillburn.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

No. Hard times, hard work.

Mosquitoes were no inducement to those who I had known in England.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

None

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Only the character of the pioneer women on the farms who gave many professional men in later years its own Victorian titles. I remember old Scottish lady who heard my cough in the night, said when I got to the door, "I knew you were coming." I was ready for her midwife duties or it was you coming. I was ready for her midwife duties or it was you coming. Or another occasion a male neighbour who slept in the manger so that he would be there if needed to go to Montana over a bloodied prairie trail for a doctor. This was the spirit of the old West.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

None in earlier years, occasional visits to neighbours within five mile radius. Home working all over needed most only had major met of the myself. Later when I got married, I remember wife and I going to church on the Sunday. I think the Methodist church was a real Godsend those days, here the women the service of worship & get together, and the Ladies Aid which help to keep up their moral.
